title: 113_s2224
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided under this Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Prevailing parties may also be awarded costs and attorney fees. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements, including costs and attorney fees for prevailing parties. Increased requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information are mandated under Section 3 of the amendment to the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for the consideration of documentation provided by consumers, such as all documentation received from or provided by the consumer. This amendment enhances the requirements for consumer reporting agencies and furnishers of information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require the review and consideration of all relevant information and documentation provided by consumers and consumer reporting agencies in disputes. The Bureau is mandated to provide reports on disputes received. The Bureau is required to gather information on disputes received by consumer reporting agencies and prescribe rules for accuracy compliance procedures in generating reports under the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The Bureau must issue a proposed rule within one year to ensure maximum accuracy of consumer reports, considering factors like matching first name, last name, date of birth, and social security number. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for maximum accuracy of consumer reports, including the disclosure of social security numbers and other relevant information. Furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies must not include new information in reinvestigations. Disclosures to consumers must include the address, telephone number, and permissible purpose of the person providing the information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for maximum accuracy of consumer reports, including the disclosure of social security numbers and other relevant information. Furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies must not include new information in reinvestigations. Disclosures to consumers must include the address, telephone number, and permissible purpose for obtaining the consumer report, including specific credit products extended or reviewed. Amendments also require supplying consumers with credit scores derived from widely distributed credit scoring models for any extension of credit or predicting future credit behavior. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for maximum accuracy of consumer reports and disclosure of credit scores to consumers upon request. Amendments also address adverse information notification requirements and redesignate subparagraphs in subsection (g)(1). The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide free disclosures to consumers upon receiving notifications under specific sections. During a transition period, agencies must give consumers their current credit report and other required disclosures without charge. Additionally, subsections in section 615 are redesignated. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to provide free disclosures to consumers. Subsections in section 615 are redesignated to include provisions for consumers to receive a copy of their consumer report free of charge. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now includes provisions for consumers to receive free disclosures of their consumer report. This includes notifying the consumer reporting agency to provide the consumer with the necessary disclosures. The Fair Credit Reporting Act has been amended to include new rules for disclosure requirements, such as notifying consumers of negative information submissions and defining certain disclosure requirements through a proposed rule by the Bureau. The Fair Credit Reporting Act has been amended to include new rules for disclosure requirements, such as verifying information accuracy and protecting consumer privacy when providing information to consumers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act has been amended to establish a registry of consumer reporting agencies, requiring all agencies to register within a specified timeframe. The Fair Credit Reporting Act has been amended to require a study by the Comptroller General on the feasibility and potential benefits of a national government-administered consumer credit reporting system. The findings must be published within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment.
